Retrieved December 9, 2016. | years_active = 1969–present | signature = Steven Spielberg Signature.svg }} '''Steven Allan Spielberg''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|KBEh}} {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic|OMRI]]}} (born December 18, 1946) is an American filmmaker. He is considered one of the founding pioneers of the [[New Hollywood]] era and one of the most popular directors and producers in film history.''The cinema of Steven Spielberg: Empire of light''. Nigel Morris. Wallflower Press. 2007 After gaining traction in Hollywood with directing television and several minor theatrical releases, Spielberg became a household name as the director of ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'' (1975), which was critically and commercially successful, and is considered the first summer [[Blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbuster]].{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Bill|title='Jaws': Revisiting Hollywood's First Summer Blockbuster|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jaws-steven-spielberg-box-office-309339|accessdate=July 10, 2016|date=April 7, 2012|work=The Hollywood Reporter}} His subsequent releases focused typically on science fiction and adventure films, with ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'' (1977), the ''[[Indiana Jones (franchise)|Indiana Jones]]'' series, ''[[E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial]]'' (1982), and the ''[[Jurassic Park]]'' series seen as archetypes of modern Hollywood [[Escapism|escapist]] filmmaking.{{cite news|title=Steven Spielberg to Harvard grads: Be the movie heroes of real life|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/steven-spielberg-to-harvard-grads-be-the-movie-heroes-of-real-life/articleshow/52463599.cms|work=The Economic Times}} Spielberg transitioned into addressing [[Humanism|humanistic]] issues in his later work via the films ''[[The Color Purple (film)|The Color Purple]]'' (1985), ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'' (1987), ''[[Schindler's List]]'' (1993), ''[[Amistad (film)|Amistad]]'' (1997) and ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]'' (1998). He has largely adhered to this practice during the 21st century, with ''[[Munich (film)|Munich]]'' (2005), ''[[Lincoln (film)|Lincoln]]'' (2012), ''[[Bridge of Spies (film)|Bridge of Spies]]'' (2015), and ''[[The Post (film)|The Post]]'' (2017). Spielberg co-founded [[Amblin Entertainment]] and [[DreamWorks|DreamWorks Studios]], where he has also served as a producer for several successful films, including the ''[[Back to the Future (franchise)|Back to the Future]]'', ''[[Men in Black (film series)|Men in Black]]'', and ''[[Transformers (film series)|Transformers]]'' series. Spielberg later transitioned into producing several games within the video-game industry. Spielberg is one of the American film industry's most critically successful filmmakers, with praise for his directing talent and versatility,{{cite web|author1=[[Matt Zoller Seitz|Seitz, Matt Zoller]]|author2=Arikan, Ali|author3=Bramble, Serena|title=MAGIC AND LIGHT: THE FILMS OF STEVEN SPIELBERG: Chapter 1: Introduction|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2011/12/magic-and-light-the-films-of-steven-spielberg-chapter-1-introduction-132598/|website=[[IndieWire]]|date=December 15, 2011|quote=The fact that Spielberg is perfectly attuned to the commercial aspects of cinema does not preclude the idea that he is a master artist, who’s worthy of appreciation and study.... The longer Spielberg directs movies, the more apparent it becomes that his is a chameleonic talent, more versatile in some ways than the talents of two of his most profound cinematic influences, Alfred Hitchcock and Walt Disney.}}{{cite news|author1=[[Manohla Dargis|Dargis, Manohla]]|author2=[[A. O. Scott|Scott, A. O.]]|title=The 25 Best Films of the 21st Century So Far.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/06/09/movies/the-25-best-films-of-the-21st-century.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=October 2, 2018|date=June 9, 2017|quote=In the 1990s, [Spielberg] made the transition from popular artist to prestige auteur.... His post-'[[Saving Private Ryan|Ryan]]' career has been distinguished by extraordinary productivity and equally remarkable range, but it hasn’t enjoyed the same level of acclaim. And yet, with characteristic verve and discipline, he has plunged into science fiction, history, politics, animation and espionage.}} and has won the [[Academy Award for Best Director]] twice.[[Academy Award for Best Director|Directors with two or more Oscars]] Some of his movies are also among the highest-grossing movies of all-time, while his total work, unadjusted for ticket-price inflation, makes him the [[List of highest-grossing directors|highest-grossing film director in history]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-milestone-steven-spielberg-is-first-member-10b-directors-club-1103623|title=Box-Office Milestone: Steven Spielberg Is First Member of $10B Directors' Club|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|date=April 17, 2018|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=April 18, 2018}} His [[net worth]] is estimated to be more than $3 billion. ==Early life== Spielberg was born on December 18, 1946 in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]].{{cite web|author=American Film Institute|url=http://www.afi.com/laa/laa95g.aspx|title=AFI Life Achievement Award|publisher=Afi.com|accessdate=October 20, 2013}} His mother, Leah (née Posner, later Adler; January 12, 1920 – February 21, 2017),{{cite web|url=http://fredbernstein.com/info/spielberg_mom.shtml|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130323023020/http://fredbernstein.com/info/spielberg_mom.shtml|title=Fred A. Bernstein|publisher=Fredbernstein.com|archivedate= March 23, 2013|accessdate=May 25, 2012}} was a restaurateur and concert pianist, and his father, [[Arnold Spielberg]] (born 1917), was an electrical engineer involved in the development of computers.{{cite web|title = Steven Spielberg Biography (1947?–)|url = http://www.filmreference.com/film/85/Steven-Spielberg.html|publisher = filmreference.com|accessdate =January 15, 2008}} His family was [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]].{{cite web|first=Zoe|last=Heller|title=FILM / The Real Thing: Steven Spielberg, fueller of fantasies, wizard|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/film-the-real-thing-steven-spielberg-fueller-of-fantasies-wizard-of-wonder-is-making-a-film-about-2324669.html|work=[[The Independent]]|date=May 22, 1993|accessdate=May 11, 2018}}{{cite news|first=Tom|last=Shales|title=THE MAN AT THE TOP OF 'SCHINDLER'S LIST'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1993/12/15/the-man-at-the-top-of-schindlers-list/22c1c36c-b62e-408c-8c4e-a06963bbb049/?tid=ss_tw|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 15, 1993|accessdate=May 11, 2018}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DbqATVZHvkQC&pg=PA35|title=Steven Spielberg: A Biography|publisher=Da Capo Press|year= 1999|isbn=978-0-306-80900-2}} Spielberg's paternal grandparents were [[History of the Jews in Ukraine|Jewish Ukrainian]]{{Cite web|url=http://birth-records.mooseroots.com/l/1321764/Arnold-Meyer-Spielberg|title=Arnold Meyer Spielberg (b. 1917)|website=birth-records.mooseroots.com|accessdate=January 10, 2018}}{{cite web|first=Sara Debbie|last=Gutfreund|title=Steven Spielberg's Jewish Roots|url=http://www.aish.com/jw/s/Steven-Spielbergs-Jewish-Roots.html|work=The Jewish Website - aish.com|date=January 28, 2017|accessdate=May 11, 2018}} immigrants who settled in Cincinnati in the 1900s; his grandmother was from [[Sudylkiv]], while his grandfather was from [[Kamianets-Podilskyi]].{{cite web| url=http://oralhistory.rutgers.edu/interviewees/30-interview-html-text/146-spielberg-arnold| title=Interview:Spielberg, Arnold| publisher=[[Rutgers University]]| date=May 12, 2006| accessdate=October 25, 2015| author=Illingworth, Shaun}}{{cite web| url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/hollywood/article/a_close_encounter_with_steven_spielbergs_dad_20120613| title=A close encounter with Steven Spielberg's dad| work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles]]| date=June 13, 2012| accessdate=October 25, 2015| author=Tugend, Tom}} In 1950, his family moved to [[Haddon Township, New Jersey]], when his father took a job with RCA. Three years later, the family moved to [[Phoenix, Arizona]].{{cite web|first=David|last=Denby|title=Steven Spielberg at Seventy|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/01/16/steven-spielberg-at-seventy|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=January 16, 2017|accessdate=May 11, 2018}}{{rp|548}} Spielberg attended Hebrew school from 1953 to 1957, in classes taught by Rabbi [[Albert L. Lewis]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DbqATVZHvkQC&pg=PA42|title=Steven Spielberg: A Biography|publisher=Da Capo Press|year= 1999|isbn=978-0-306-80900-2}} As a child, Spielberg faced difficulty reconciling being an Orthodox Jew with the perception of him by other children he played with. "It isn't something I enjoy admitting," he once said, "but when I was seven, eight, nine years old, God forgive me, I was embarrassed because we were Orthodox Jews. I was embarrassed by the outward perception of my parents' Jewish practices. I was never really ashamed to be Jewish, but I was uneasy at times."{{cite web|first=Slovie|last=Jungreis-Wolff|title=Steven Spielberg, E.T. and Growing Up Jewish|url=http://www.aish.com/f/p/Steven-Spielberg-ET-and-Growing-Up-Jewish.html|work=The Jewish Website - aish.com|date=August 22, 2015|accessdate=May 11, 2018}}{{cite news|title=Steven Spielberg: 'We Can't Just Sit Back and Hope'|publisher=Parade Magazine|date=March 27, 1994|url=http://www.parade.com/articles/editions/1994/edition_03-27-1994/steven-spielberg-we-cant-just-sit-back-and-hope.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202024010/https://parade.com/articles/editions/1994/edition_03-27-1994/steven-spielberg-we-cant-just-sit-back-and-hope.html|archivedate=February 2, 2016|df= }} Spielberg also said he suffered from acts of [[anti-Semitic]] prejudice and bullying: "In high school, I got smacked and kicked around. Two bloody noses. It was horrible."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/packages/html/movies/bestpictures/schindler-ar1.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|first=Bernard|last=Weinraub|date=December 12, 1993|title=Steven Spielberg Faces the Holocaust}}{{cite journal|first=Noah|last=Isenberg|title=The Making of Steven Spielberg|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/139708/making-steven-spielberg|journal=[[The New Republic]]|date=January 9, 2017|accessdate=May 11, 2018}}{{cite web|first=J.D.|last=Reed|title=Steven Spielberg|url=http://people.com/archive/steven-spielberg/|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=March 15, 1999|accessdate=May 11, 2018}} At age 12, he made his first home movie: a train wreck involving his toy [[Lionel Corporation|Lionel]] trains.{{cite book|last1=Sanello|first1=Frank|title=Spielberg: The Man, the Movies, the Mythology|date=2002|publisher=Taylor Trade Publications|page=14|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A6hmQbfOeTAC&pg=PA14#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=April 21, 2015|isbn=9780878331482}} Throughout his early teens, and after entering high school, Spielberg continued to make amateur 8 mm "adventure" films.{{cite book|last1=Jackson|first1=Kathi|title=Steven Spielberg: A Biography|date=2007|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|page=5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SwkUdUXRA_kC&pg=PA5#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=April 21, 2015|isbn=9780313337963}} In 1958, he became a [[Boy Scouting (Boy Scouts of America)|Boy Scout]] and fulfilled a requirement for the [[Merit badge (Boy Scouts of America)|photography merit badge]] by making a nine-minute 8 mm film entitled ''The Last Gunfight''.{{cite web| title = Steven Spielberg Sighted in Arizona|url = http://doney.net/aroundaz/celebrity/spielberg_stephen.htm| accessdate =November 19, 2007}} Years later, Spielberg recalled to a magazine interviewer, "My dad's still-camera was broken, so I asked the scoutmaster if I could tell a story with my father's movie camera. He said yes, and I got an idea to do a Western. I made it and got my merit badge. That was how it all started."{{cite web|title=Nickelodeon Magazine Interviews Steven Spielberg|work=[[Nickelodeon Magazine]]|url=http://www.nick.com/shows/nick_mag/lookInside/index.jhtml?pagenum=8|accessdate=July 29, 2008}} At age 13, while living in Phoenix, Spielberg won a prize for a 40-minute war film he titled ''Escape to Nowhere''… using a cast composed of other high school friends. That motivated him to make 15 more amateur 8 mm films.{{rp|548}} In 1963, at age 16, Spielberg wrote and directed his first independent film, a 140-minute science fiction adventure called ''[[Firelight (1964 film)|Firelight]]'', which would later inspire ''Close Encounters''. The film was made for $500, most of which came from his father, and was shown in a local cinema for one evening, which earned back its cost.From Inside the Actor's Studio with James Lipton interviewing Steven Spielberg. After attending [[Arcadia High School (Phoenix, Arizona)|Arcadia High School]] in Phoenix for three years, his family next moved to [[Saratoga, California]], where he later graduated from [[Saratoga High School (California)|Saratoga High School]] in 1965. He attained the rank of [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]]. His parents divorced while he was still in school,{{cite news|last1=Weisman|first1=Aly|title=Meet Steven Spielberg's Parents In This Revealing '60 Minutes' Profile|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/meet-steven-spielbergs-parents-in-this-revealing-60-minutes-profile-2012-10|accessdate=September 29, 2016|publisher=Business Insider|date=October 22, 2012}} and soon after he graduated Spielberg moved to [[Los Angeles]], staying initially with his father. His long-term goal was to become a film director. His three sisters and mother remained in Saratoga. In Los Angeles, he applied to the [[University of Southern California]]'s film school, but was turned down because of his "C" grade average.Fischer, Dennis. ''Science Fiction Film Directors, 1895–1998'', McFarland & Co. (2000){{rp|548}} He then applied and was admitted to [[California State University, Long Beach]], where he became a brother of [[Theta Chi Fraternity]].[http://www.thetachi.org/about/notable-theta-chis/ "Notable Theta Chis"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418075922/http://www.thetachi.org/about/notable-theta-chis/|date=April 18, 2015 }}, Theta Chi Fraternity alumni While still a student, he was offered a small unpaid intern job at [[Universal Studios]] with the editing department.{{cite web|url=http://www.usc.edu/about/administration/trustees/|title=Board of Trustees – About USC|work=usc.edu|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726020808/http://www.usc.edu/about/administration/trustees/|archivedate=July 26, 2011|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.calstate.edu/Newsline/Archive/01-02/020514-LB.shtml|title=CSU Newsline – Steven Spielberg To Graduate from California State University, Long Beach With Bachelor's Degree in Film and Electronic Arts|publisher=Calstate.edu|date=May 14, 2002|accessdate=March 2, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100309122336/https://www.calstate.edu/Newsline/Archive/01-02/020514-LB.shtml|archivedate=March 9, 2010|df= }} He was later given the opportunity to make a short film for theatrical release, the 26-minute, 35 mm, ''[[Amblin']]'', which he wrote and directed. Studio vice president [[Sidney Sheinberg]] was impressed by the film, which had won a number of awards, and offered Spielberg a seven-year directing contract. It made him the youngest director ever to be signed for a long-term deal with a major Hollywood studio.{{rp|548}} He subsequently dropped out of college to begin professionally directing TV productions with Universal.{{Cite news| url =http://articles.latimes.com/2002/may/31/local/me-graduate31|title= Spielberg to Add B.A. to His Resume|author= Stephanie Chavez|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date =May 31, 2002}}{{Cite news| url = https://www.nytimes.com/times-insider/2014/06/26/first-glimpses-spielberg-and-snow-white/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|title=1969: Spielberg and Snow White|author=Mark Bulik|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date = June 26, 2014}} Spielberg later returned to [[California State University, Long Beach]] and completed his BA degree in Film and Electronic Arts in 2002.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/3579578/Spielberg-why-I-went-back-to-college.html|title=Spielberg: why I went back to college|first=John|last=Hiscock|date=June 30, 2002|accessdate=December 1, 2017|website=Telegraph.co.uk}} ==Career== ===1970s=== His first professional TV job came when he was hired to direct one of the segments for the 1969 pilot episode of ''[[Night Gallery (film)|Night Gallery]]'', written by [[Rod Serling]] and starring [[Joan Crawford]].{{Cite news| url =https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0064725/|title= Night Gallery|publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]]|accessdate = July 21, 2014}} Crawford, however, was "speechless, and then horrified" at the thought of a twenty-one-year-old newcomer directing her, one of Hollywood's leading stars. "Why was this happening to me?" she asked the producer.Chandler, Charlotte. ''Not the Girl Next Door: Joan Crawford, a Personal Biography'', Hal Leonard Corp. (2008) p. 261 Her attitude changed after they began working on her scenes: {{quote|When I began to work with Steven, I understood everything. It was immediately obvious to me, and probably everyone else, that here was a young genius. I thought maybe more experience was important, but then I thought of all of those experienced directors who didn't have Steven's intuitive inspiration and who just kept repeating the same old routine performances. ''That'' was called "experience." I knew then that Steven Spielberg had a brilliant future ahead of him. Hollywood doesn't always recognize talent, but Steven's was not going to be overlooked. I told him so in a note I wrote him. I wrote to Rod Serling, too. I was so grateful that he had approved Steven as the director. I told him he had been totally right.}} She and Spielberg were reportedly close friends until her death. The episode is unusual in his body of work, in that the camerawork is more highly stylized than his later, more "mature" films. After this, and an episode of ''[[Marcus Welby, M.D.]]'', Spielberg got his first feature-length assignment: an episode of ''[[The Name of the Game (TV series)|The Name of the Game]]'' called "[[L.A. 2017]]". This futuristic science fiction episode impressed Universal Studios and they signed him to a short contract. He did another segment on ''Night Gallery'' and did some work for shows such as ''[[Owen Marshall: Counselor at Law]]'' and ''The Psychiatrist'', before landing the first series episode of ''[[Columbo (TV series)|Columbo]]'' (previous episodes were actually TV films). Based on the strength of his work, Universal signed Spielberg to do four TV films. The first was a [[Richard Matheson]] adaptation called ''[[Duel (1971 film)|Duel]]''. The film is about a psychotic [[Peterbilt 281]] [[tanker truck]] driver who chases the terrified driver ([[Dennis Weaver]]) of a small [[Plymouth Valiant]] and tries to run him off the road. Special praise of this film by the influential British critic [[Dilys Powell]] was highly significant to Spielberg's career. Another TV film (''[[Something Evil]]'') was made and released to capitalize on the popularity of ''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]'', then a major best-selling book which had not yet been released as a film. He fulfilled his contract by directing the TV film-length pilot of a show called ''Savage'', starring [[Martin Landau]]. Spielberg's debut full-length feature film was ''[[The Sugarland Express]]'', about a married couple who are chased by police as the couple tries to regain custody of their baby. Spielberg's cinematography for the police chase was praised by reviewers, and ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' stated that "a major new director is on the horizon."{{rp|223}} However, the film fared poorly at the box office and received a limited release. Studio producers [[Richard D. Zanuck]] and [[David Brown (producer)|David Brown]] offered Spielberg the director's chair for ''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'', a thriller-horror film based on the [[Peter Benchley]] novel [[Jaws (novel)|about an enormous killer shark]]. Spielberg has often referred to the gruelling shoot as his professional crucible. Despite the film's ultimate, enormous success, it was nearly shut down due to delays and budget over-runs. But Spielberg persevered and finished the film. It was an enormous hit, winning three Academy Awards (for editing, original score and sound) and grossing more than $470 million worldwide at the box office. It also set the domestic record for box office gross, leading to what the press described as "Jawsmania."{{rp|248}} ''Jaws'' made Spielberg a household name and one of America's youngest multi-millionaires, allowing him a great deal of autonomy for his future projects.{{rp|250}} It was nominated for Best Picture and featured Spielberg's first of three collaborations with actor [[Richard Dreyfuss]]. Rejecting offers to direct ''[[Jaws 2]]'',{{cite book|last=Baxter|first=John|year=1997|title=Steven Spielberg: The Unauthorised Biography|location=London|publisher=Harper Collins|page=145|isbn=978-0-00-638444-1}} ''[[King Kong (1976 film)|King Kong]]'' and ''[[Superman (1978 film)|Superman]]'', Spielberg and actor Richard Dreyfuss re-convened to work on a film about [[Unidentified flying object|UFOs]], which became ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'' (1977). One of the rare films both written and directed by Spielberg, ''Close Encounters'' was a critical and box office hit, giving Spielberg his first Best Director nomination from the Academy as well as earning six other [[Academy Awards]] nominations. It won Oscars in two categories (Cinematography, [[Vilmos Zsigmond]], and a Special Achievement Award for Sound Effects Editing, Frank E. Warner). This second blockbuster helped to secure Spielberg's rise. His next film, ''[[1941 (film)|1941]]'', a big-budgeted World War II farce, was not nearly as successful and though it grossed over $92.4 million worldwide (and did make a small profit for co-producing studios Columbia and Universal) it was seen as a disappointment, mainly with the critics.[http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1979/01941.php "1941, Box Office Information."] ''The Numbers'', September 27, 2012. Spielberg then revisited his ''Close Encounters'' project and, with financial backing from Columbia Pictures, released ''Close Encounters: The Special Edition'' in 1980. For this, Spielberg fixed some of the flaws he thought impeded the original 1977 version of the film and also, at the behest of Columbia, and as a condition of Spielberg revising the film, shot additional footage showing the audience the interior of the mothership seen at the end of the film (a decision Spielberg would later regret as he felt the interior of the mothership should have remained a mystery). Nevertheless, the re-release was a moderate success, while the 2001 DVD release of the film restored the original ending. ===1980s=== Next, Spielberg teamed with ''[[Star Wars]]'' creator and friend [[George Lucas]] on an action adventure film, ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]'', the first of the [[Indiana Jones]] films. The archaeologist and adventurer hero Indiana Jones was played by [[Harrison Ford]] (whom Lucas had previously cast in his ''[[Star Wars]]'' films as [[Han Solo]]). The film was considered an homage to the cliffhanger serials of the [[Golden Age of Hollywood]]. It became the biggest film at the box office in 1981, and the recipient of numerous Oscar nominations including Best Director (Spielberg's second nomination) and Best Picture (the second Spielberg film to be nominated for Best Picture). ''Raiders'' is still considered a landmark example of the action-adventure genre. The film also led to Ford's casting in [[Ridley Scott]]'s ''[[Blade Runner]]''.{{cite web|title=Blade Runner|url=http://www.gradesaver.com/blade-runner/wikipedia/casting-and-characters/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820185400/https://www.gradesaver.com/blade-runner/wikipedia/casting-and-characters/|archivedate=August 20, 2011|df= }} A year later, Spielberg returned to the science fiction genre with ''[[E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial]]''. It was the story of a young boy and the alien he befriends, who was accidentally left behind by his companions and is attempting to return home. ''E.T.'' went on to become the top-grossing film of all time. It was also nominated for nine Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Director and it won 4 out of them.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/oct/21/et-spielberg-fantasy|title=ET: The Extra-Terrestrial: No 7 best sci-fi and fantasy film of all time|last=Wise|first=Damon|date=October 21, 2010|work=The Guardian|access-date=October 18, 2017|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} Between 1982 and 1985, Spielberg produced three high-grossing films: ''[[Poltergeist (1982 film)|Poltergeist]]'' (for which he also co-wrote the screenplay), a big-screen adaptation of ''[[Twilight Zone: The Movie|The Twilight Zone]]'' (for which he directed the segment "Kick The Can"),{{cite web|url = http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1556111/story.jhtml|title= Rewind: Major-Studio flicks that belong in the Grind House|first = Karl|last = Heitmueller|date = April 3, 2007|accessdate =January 2, 2009|publisher = MTV|quote = Ultimate A-lister Steven Spielberg co-produced this big-budget adaptation of Rod Serling's classic '60s TV show....}} and ''[[The Goonies]]'' (Spielberg, executive producer, also wrote the story on which the screenplay was based).{{cite journal|title = This way to the children's crusade|first = Richard|last = Corliss|date = January 7, 1985|accessdate =January 2, 2009|quote = he wrote the story and served as an executive producer of The Goonies....|url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,959559,00.html|journal = [[Time (magazine)|Time]]}} Spielberg appeared in a cameo on [[Cyndi Lauper]]'s music video for the movie's theme song, "[[The Goonies 'R' Good Enough]]".{{youtube|LxLhytQ67fs|Cyndi Lauper – The Goonies 'R' Good Enough}} [[File:Steven Spielberg with Chandran Rutnam in Sri Lanka.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|right|Steven Spielberg and [[Chandran Rutnam]] on a location in Sri Lanka during the filming of ''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]''.]] His next directorial feature was the ''Raiders'' prequel ''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]''. Teaming up once again with Lucas and Ford, the film was plagued with uncertainty for the material and script. This film and the Spielberg-produced ''[[Gremlins]]'' led to the creation of the [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|PG-13 rating]] due to the high level of violence in films targeted at younger audiences. In spite of this, ''Temple of Doom'' is rated PG by the MPAA, even though it is the darkest and, possibly, most violent Indy film. Nonetheless, the film was still a huge blockbuster hit in 1984. It was on this project that Spielberg also met his future wife, actress [[Kate Capshaw]].{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/articles/Steven-Spielberg-9490621|title=Steven Spielberg Biography|publisher=Biography.com|date=December 18, 1947|accessdate=January 31, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514201106/https://www.biography.com/articles/Steven-Spielberg-9490621|archivedate=May 14, 2011|df=}} In 1985, Spielberg released ''[[The Color Purple (film)|The Color Purple]],'' an adaptation of [[Alice Walker]]'s [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning [[The Color Purple|novel of the same name]], about a generation of empowered African-American women during depression-era America. Starring [[Whoopi Goldberg]] and future talk-show superstar [[Oprah Winfrey]], the film was a box office smash and critics hailed Spielberg's successful foray into the dramatic genre. [[Roger Ebert]] proclaimed it the best film of the year and later entered it into his Great Films archive. The film received eleven [[Academy Award]] nominations, including two for Goldberg and Winfrey. However, Spielberg did not get a Best Director nomination. In 1987, as China began opening to Western capital investment, Spielberg shot the first American film in Shanghai since the 1930s, an adaptation of [[J. G. Ballard]]'s autobiographical novel ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'', starring [[John Malkovich]] and a young [[Christian Bale]]. The film garnered much praise from critics and was nominated for several Oscars, but did not yield substantial box office revenues. Reviewer [[Andrew Sarris]] called it the best film of the year and later included it among the best films of the decade.{{cite web| title = Andrew Sarris' Top 10 lists 1958–2005| url = http://alumnus.caltech.edu/~ejohnson/critics/sarris.html#y1977| accessdate =October 21, 2006}} Spielberg was also a co-producer of the 1987 film ''[[Batteries Not Included|*batteries not included]]''. After two forays into more serious dramatic films, Spielberg then directed the third Indiana Jones film, 1989's ''[[Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade]]''. Once again teaming up with Lucas and Ford, Spielberg also cast actor [[Sean Connery]] in a supporting role as Indy's father. The film earned generally positive reviews and was another box office success, becoming the highest-grossing film worldwide that year; its total box office receipts even topped those of Tim Burton's much-anticipated film ''[[Batman (1989 film)|Batman]]'', which had been the bigger hit domestically. Also in 1989, he re-united with actor [[Richard Dreyfuss]] for the romantic comedy-drama ''[[Always (1989 film)|Always]]'', about a daredevil pilot who extinguishes forest fires. Spielberg's first romantic film, ''Always'' was only a moderate success and had mixed reviews. ===1990s=== [[File:Spielberg1990.jpg|thumb|left|Spielberg in March 1990]] In 1991, Spielberg directed ''[[Hook (film)|Hook]]'', about a middle-aged [[Peter Pan]], played by [[Robin Williams]], who returns to [[Neverland]]. Despite innumerable rewrites and creative changes coupled with mixed reviews, the film proved popular with audiences, making over $300 million worldwide (from a $70 million budget). In 1993, Spielberg returned to the adventure genre with the film version of [[Michael Crichton]]'s novel ''[[Jurassic Park (film)|Jurassic Park]]'', about a theme park with genetically engineered dinosaurs. With revolutionary special effects provided by friend [[George Lucas]]'s [[Industrial Light & Magic]] company, the film would eventually become the highest-grossing film of all time (at the worldwide box office) with $914.7 million. This would be the third time that one of Spielberg's films became the highest-grossing film ever. Spielberg's next film, ''[[Schindler's List]]'', was based on the true story of [[Oskar Schindler]], a man who risked his life to save 1,100 Jews from the Holocaust.The screenplay, adapted from [[Thomas Keneally]]'s novel, was originally in the hands of fellow director [[Martin Scorsese]], but Spielberg negotiated with Scorsese to trade scripts. (At the time, Spielberg held the script for a remake of ''[[Cape Fear (1962 film)|Cape Fear]]''.) ''Schindler's List'' earned Spielberg his first [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] (it also won [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]). With the film a huge success at the box office, Spielberg used the profits to set up the [[Shoah Foundation]], a non-profit organization that archives filmed testimony of Holocaust survivors. In 1997, the [[American Film Institute]] listed it among the 10 Greatest American Films ever Made (#9) which moved up to (#8) when the list was remade in 2007. In 1994, Spielberg took a hiatus from directing to spend more time with his family and build his new studio, [[DreamWorks]],{{cite news|author = Army Archered|title = Spielberg to take break after completing 'List'|publisher = Variety|date = June 17, 1993|url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117862199.html?categoryid=2&cs=1&query=dark+AND+angel|accessdate =February 11, 2007}} with partners [[Jeffrey Katzenberg]] and [[David Geffen]]. In 1996, he directed the sequel to 1993's ''Jurassic Park'' with ''[[The Lost World: Jurassic Park]]'', which generated over $618 million worldwide despite mixed reviews, and was the second biggest film of 1997 behind [[James Cameron]]'s ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'' (which topped the original ''Jurassic Park'' to become the new recordholder for box office receipts). [[File:Steven Spielberg - GianAngelo Pistoia 1.jpg|thumb|right|Spielberg in 1993]] His next film, ''[[Amistad (film)|Amistad]]'', was based on a true story (like ''Schindler's List''), specifically about an African slave rebellion. Despite decent reviews from critics, it did not do well at the box office. Spielberg released ''Amistad'' under DreamWorks Pictures,(formed with former [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] animation exec [[Jeffrey Katzenberg]] and media mogul [[David Geffen]], providing the other letters in the company name) which has produced all of his films from ''Amistad'' onwards with the exception of ''[[Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull]]'', ''[[The Adventures of Tintin (film)|The Adventures of Tintin]]'' and ''[[Ready Player One (film)|Ready Player One]]''.{{cite news|last1=Masters|first1=Kim|title=Steven Spielberg on DreamWorks' Past, Amblin's Present and His Own Future|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/features/steven-spielberg-dreamworks-past-amblins-902544|accessdate=July 11, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 15, 2016}} His 1998 theatrical release was the World War II film ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]'', about a group of U.S. soldiers led by Capt. Miller ([[Tom Hanks]]) sent to bring home a [[paratrooper]] whose three older brothers were killed in the same twenty-four hours, June 5–6, of the Normandy landing. The film was a huge box office success, grossing over $481 million worldwide and was the biggest film of the year at the North American box office (worldwide it made second place after Michael Bay's ''[[Armageddon (1998 film)|Armageddon]]''). Spielberg won his second Academy Award for his direction. The film's graphic, realistic depiction of combat violence influenced later war films such as ''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]'' and ''[[Enemy at the Gates]]''. The film was also the first major hit for DreamWorks, which co-produced the film with [[Paramount Pictures]] (as such, it was Spielberg's first release from the latter that was not part of the ''Indiana Jones'' series). Later, Spielberg and [[Tom Hanks]] produced a [[Band of Brothers (TV miniseries)|TV mini-series]] based on [[Stephen Ambrose]]'s book ''[[Band of Brothers (book)|Band of Brothers]]''. The ten-part [[HBO]] mini-series follows Easy Company of the [[101st Airborne Division]]'s 506th Parachute Infantry Regiment. The series won a number of awards at the [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globes]] and the [[Emmy Award|Emmys]]. ===2000s=== In 2001, Spielberg filmed fellow director and friend [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s final project, ''[[A.I. Artificial Intelligence]]'' which Kubrick was unable to begin during his lifetime. A futuristic film about a humanoid [[android (robot)|android]] longing for love, ''A.I.'' featured groundbreaking visual effects and a multi-layered, allegorical storyline, adapted by Spielberg himself. Though the film's reception in the US was relatively muted, it performed better overseas for a worldwide total box office gross of $236 million. Spielberg and actor [[Tom Cruise]] collaborated for the first time for the futuristic [[neo-noir]] ''[[Minority Report (film)|Minority Report]]'', based upon [[The Minority Report|the science fiction short story]] written by [[Philip K. Dick]] about a Washington D.C. police captain in the year 2054 who has been foreseen to murder a man he has not yet met. The film received strong reviews with the review tallying website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] giving it a 92% approval rating, reporting that 206 out of the 225 reviews they tallied were positive.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/minority_report/|title=Minority Report|last=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|date=|website=|accessdate=April 10, 2018}} The film earned over $358 million worldwide. [[Roger Ebert]], who named it the best film of 2002, praised its breathtaking vision of the future as well as for the way Spielberg blended [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] with live-action.{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20020621/REVIEWS/206210304/1023|title=Minority Report|last=Ebert|first=Roger|date=June 21, 2002|work=Chicago Sun-Times|accessdate=April 10, 2018|authorlink=Roger Ebert}} Spielberg's 2002 film ''[[Catch Me If You Can]]'' is about the daring adventures of a youthful con artist (played by [[Leonardo DiCaprio]]). It earned [[Christopher Walken]] an Academy Award nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]]. The film is known for [[John Williams]]'s score and its unique [[title sequence]]. It was a hit both commercially{{cite web| url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=catchmeifyoucan.htm| title=Box office collection of Catch Me If You Can| accessdate=November 19, 2012}} and critically.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/catch_me_if_you_can/|title=Reviews of Catch Me If You Can|last=|first=|date=|website=|accessdate=April 10, 2018}} Spielberg collaborated again with Tom Hanks along with [[Catherine Zeta-Jones]] and [[Stanley Tucci]] in 2004's ''[[The Terminal]]'', a warm-hearted comedy about a man of Eastern European descent who is stranded in an airport. It received mixed reviews but performed relatively well at the box office. In 2005, ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' magazine ranked Spielberg number one on a list of the greatest film directors of all time. Also in 2005, Spielberg directed a modern adaptation of ''[[War of the Worlds (2005 film)|War of the Worlds]]'' (a co-production of Paramount and DreamWorks), based on the H. G. Wells book of the same name (Spielberg had been a huge fan of the book and the original 1953 film). It starred Tom Cruise and [[Dakota Fanning]], and, as with past Spielberg films, [[Industrial Light & Magic]] (ILM) provided the [[visual effects]]. Unlike ''E.T.'' and ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind'', which depicted friendly alien visitors, ''War of the Worlds'' featured violent invaders. The film was another huge box office smash, grossing over $591 million worldwide. Spielberg's film ''[[Munich (film)|Munich]]'', about the events following the 1972 [[Munich Massacre]] of Israeli athletes at the Olympic Games, was his second film essaying Jewish relations in the world (the first being ''Schindler's List''). The film is based on ''[[Vengeance (Jonas book)|Vengeance]]'', a book by Canadian journalist [[George Jonas]]. It was previously adapted into the 1986 made-for-TV film ''[[Sword of Gideon]]''. The film received strong critical praise, but underperformed at the U.S. and world box-office; it remains one of Spielberg's most controversial films to date.{{Cite news|author=Yossi Melman and Steven Hartov|date=January 17, 2006|title=Munich: Fact and Fantasy|url=https://www.theguardian.com/comment/story/0,3604,1687815,00.html|publisher=The Guardian Unlimited|volume=|pages=|accessdate=April 10, 2018|via=|newspaper=The Guardian}} ''Munich'' received five Academy Awards nominations, including Best Picture, Film Editing, Original Music Score (by John Williams), Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Director for Spielberg. It was Spielberg's sixth Best Director nomination and fifth Best Picture nomination. In June 2006, Steven Spielberg announced he would direct a [[Hard science fiction|scientifically accurate]] film about "a group of explorers who travel through a worm hole and into another dimension",{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117945326.html|title=Space chase pic on Par launch pad|author=Michael Fleming|first=|date=June 14, 2006|work=Variety|accessdate=April 10, 2018}} from a treatment by [[Kip Thorne]] and producer [[Lynda Obst]].{{cite news|author=Jay A. Fernandez|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/movies/la-et-scriptland28mar28,1,3123129.story?track=rss&ctrack=1&cset=true|title=Jonah Nolan turns science into a film script|work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 28, 2007|accessdate=March 28, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202012203/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/movies/la-et-scriptland28mar28%2C1%2C3123129.story?track=rss&ctrack=1&cset=true|archivedate=December 2, 2008|df= }} In January 2007, screenwriter [[Jonathan Nolan]] met with them to discuss adapting Obst and Thorne's treatment into a narrative screenplay. The screenwriter suggested the addition of a "time element" to the treatment's basic idea, which was welcomed by Obst and Thorne. In March of that year, Paramount hired Nolan, as well as scientists from [[Caltech]], forming a workshop to adapt the treatment under the title ''[[Interstellar (film)|Interstellar]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117961655.html|title=Nolan to write Spielberg film|author=Michael Fleming|first=|date=March 22, 2007|work=Variety|accessdate=April 10, 2018}} The following July, Kip Thorne said there was a push by people for him to portray himself in the film.{{cite news| author=Leigh Dayton| url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,22071820-30417,00.html| title=Warped in La La Land| work=The Australian| date=July 14, 2007| accessdate=July 20, 2007| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110002631/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,22071820-30417,00.html#| archive-date=November 10, 2007| dead-url=yes| df=mdy-all}} Spielberg later abandoned ''Interstellar'', which was eventually directed by [[Christopher Nolan]].{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben|title=Christopher Nolan's next film mission to go Interstellar|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/jan/10/christopher-nolan-next-film-interstellar|newspaper=The Guardian|date=January 10, 2013}} Spielberg directed ''[[Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull]]'', which wrapped filming in October 2007 and was released on May 22, 2008.{{Cite news|title = New Indy Adventure Begins Shooting|publisher = IndianaJones.com|date = June 18, 2007|url = http://www.indianajones.com/community/news/news20070618.html|accessdate =June 18, 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070621003713/http://indianajones.com/community/news/news20070618.html|archivedate = June 21, 2007}}{{cite news|title = Spielberg, Ford and Lucas on Indy IV| work = Empire| date = August 21, 2006| url = http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=19382| accessdate =October 21, 2006}} This was his first film not to be released by DreamWorks since 1997. The film received generally positive reviews from critics,{{cite web|title=Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/indiana_jones_and_the_kingdom_of_the_crystal_skull/|accessdate=April 12, 2012}} and was financially successful, grossing $786 million worldwide. ===2010s=== [[File:Steven Spielberg Masterclass Cinémathèque Française 2 cropped.jpg|thumb|left|Spielberg at his masterclass at the [[Cinémathèque Française]] in January 2012.]] In early 2009, Spielberg shot the first film in a planned trilogy of [[motion capture]] films based on ''[[The Adventures of Tintin]]'', written by Belgian artist [[Hergé]],[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/23/books/23book.html "The Man Behind Boy, Dog and Their Adventures"] Book review by [[Charles McGrath]], ''The New York Times'', December 22, 2009 (December 23, 2009, p. C1 NY ed.). Book reviewed: ''Hergé: The Man Who Created Tintin'', by Pierre Assouline; translated by Charles Ruas, 276 pages. Oxford University Press. Retrieved December 24, 2009. with [[Peter Jackson]]. ''[[The Adventures of Tintin: The Secret of the Unicorn]]'', was not released until October 2011, due to the complexity of the computer animation involved. The world premiere took place on October 22, 2011 in [[Brussels]], Belgium.{{cite news|title=Tintin Has World Premiere in His Hometown|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=141619935|accessdate=October 22, 2011|newspaper=NPR|date=October 22, 2011|agency=Associated Press}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The film was released in North American theaters on December 21, 2011, in [[Digital 3D]] and [[IMAX 3D|IMAX]].{{cite web|url=http://www.us.movie.tintin.com|title=The Adventures of Tintin Official Movie Site|publisher=Paramount Pictures|accessdate=October 13, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111013183713/http://www.us.movie.tintin.com/|archivedate=October 13, 2011|df=mdy }} It received generally positive reviews from critics,{{cite web|title=The Adventures of Tintin (Rotten Tomatoes)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_adventures_of_tintin/|accessdate=April 12, 2012}} and grossed over $373 million worldwide.{{cite web|title=The Adventures of Tintin (Box office)|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=tintin.htm|accessdate=April 12, 2012}} ''The Adventures of Tintin'' won the award for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film|Best Animated Feature Film]] at the [[69th Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]] that year.{{cite web|title=2012 GOLDEN GLOBES Nominees and Winners – Complete List!|url=http://broadwayworld.com/article/2012-GOLDEN-GLOBES-Are-Tonight-BroadwayWorld-to-Update-Winners-LIVE-20120115|accessdate=April 15, 2012}} It is the first non-[[Pixar]] film to win the award since the category was first introduced.{{cite web|title=Tintin Takes Golden Globe|url=http://www.pixarportal.com/blog.php?id=tintin-takes-golden-globe|accessdate=April 12, 2012}}{{cite web|title=The Adventures of Tintin (Trivia)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0983193/trivia|accessdate=April 12, 2012}} Jackson has been announced to direct the second film.{{cite web|last=Wigler|first=Josh|title=Jackson To Direct 'Tintin' Sequel|url=http://splashpage.mtv.com/2011/10/26/peter-jackson-tintin-hobbit/|publisher=MTV|accessdate=October 26, 2011|date=October 26, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028074216/http://splashpage.mtv.com/2011/10/26/peter-jackson-tintin-hobbit/|archivedate=October 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Spielberg followed with ''[[War Horse (film)|War Horse]]'', shot in England in the summer of 2010.[http://www.thisisplymouth.co.uk/news/SPIELBERG-FILMS-DARTMOOR/article-2482773-detail/article.html "Steven Spielberg starts filming War Horse on Dartmoor"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110425134559/http://www.thisisplymouth.co.uk/news/SPIELBERG-FILMS-DARTMOOR/article-2482773-detail/article.html|date=April 25, 2011 }} by Tristan Nichols, ''The Herald'' August 3, 2010 It was released just four days after ''The Adventures of Tintin'', on December 25, 2011. The film, based on the [[War Horse (book)|novel]] of the same name written by [[Michael Morpurgo]] and published in 1982, follows the long friendship between a British boy and his horse Joey before and during World War I – the novel was also adapted into a hit [[War Horse (play)|play]] in London which is still running there, as well as on Broadway. Distributed by [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios]], with whom DreamWorks made a distribution deal in 2009, ''War Horse'' was the first of four consecutive Spielberg films released by Disney. ''War Horse'' received generally positive reviews from critics,{{cite web|title=War Horse (Rotten Tomatoes)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/war_horse/|accessdate=April 12, 2012}} and was nominated for six [[Academy Awards]], including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]].{{cite web|title=Nominees and Winners for the 84th Academy Awards|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/84/nominees.html|work=oscars.org|accessdate=April 12, 2012}} Spielberg next directed the [[historical drama film]] ''[[Lincoln (film)|Lincoln]]'', starring [[Daniel Day-Lewis]] as United States President [[Abraham Lincoln]] and [[Sally Field]] as [[Mary Todd Lincoln]].{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/04/13/spielbergs-lincoln-gets-its-mary-todd-sally-field|title=Steven Spielberg's 'Lincoln' gets its Mary Todd: Sally Field|author=Breznican, Anthony|date=April 13, 2011|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=June 28, 2011}} Based on [[Doris Kearns Goodwin]]'s bestseller ''[[Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln]]'', the film covered the final four months of Lincoln's life. Written by [[Tony Kushner]], the film was shot in Richmond, Virginia, in late 2011,{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc12.com/story/14601466/first-casting-calls-for-steven-spielberg-movie|title=First casting calls for Steven Spielberg movie|first=Ben|last=Garbarek|publisher=WWBT (Richmond)|date=May 9, 2011|accessdate=July 20, 2011}} and was released in the United States in November 2012.{{cite web|url=http://thisweekinthecivilwar.com/2011/10/05/spielberg-to-film-lincoln-scenes-in-richmond/|title=This Week in the Civil War|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140411133150/https://thisweekinthecivilwar.com/2011/10/05/spielberg-to-film-lincoln-scenes-in-richmond/|archivedate=April 11, 2014|df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/daniel-day-lewis-lincoln-steven-spielberg/|title=Daniel Day-Lewis to Star in Steven Spielberg's 'Lincoln'|work=[[/Film]]|author=Fischer, Russ|date=November 19, 2010}} Upon release, ''Lincoln'' received widespread critical acclaim,{{cite web|url= http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lincoln_2011/|title=Lincoln|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]| accessdate=November 15, 2012 }} and was nominated for twelve [[Academy Awards]] (the most of any film that year) including Best Picture and Best Director for Spielberg.{{cite web|title=Nominees for the 85th Academy Awards|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/85/nominees.html|work=oscars.org|accessdate=March 3, 2013}} It won the award for [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Best Production Design]] and Day-Lewis won the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] for his portrayal of Lincoln, becoming the first three-time winner in that category as well as the first to win for a performance directed by Spielberg. It was announced on May 2, 2013, that Spielberg would direct the film about the story of U.S. [[sniper]] [[Chris Kyle]], titled ''[[American Sniper]]''.{{cite web|title=Steven Spielberg, Bradley Cooper to team for 'American Sniper'|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-steven-spielberg-bradley-cooper-to-team-on-american-sniper-20130502,0,6075950.story|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=May 3, 2013}} However, on August 5, 2013, it was announced that Spielberg had decided not to direct the film, which was instead directed by [[Clint Eastwood]].{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=Steven Spielberg, DreamWorks Part Ways With 'American Sniper'|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/steven-spielberg-american-sniper-1200566895/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=August 5, 2013}} [[File:Ready Player One Japan Premiere Red Carpet Steven Spielberg (40713131765) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Spielberg promoting ''[[Ready Player One (film)|Ready Player One]]'' (2018) in Japan.]] Spielberg directed 2015's ''[[Bridge of Spies (film)|Bridge of Spies]]'', a Cold War thriller based on the [[1960 U-2 incident]], and focusing on [[James B. Donovan]]'s negotiations with the Soviets for the release of pilot [[Gary Powers]] after his aircraft was shot down over Soviet territory. The film starred [[Tom Hanks]] as Donovan, as well as [[Mark Rylance]], [[Amy Ryan]], and [[Alan Alda]], with a script by the [[Coen brothers]].{{cite news|last1=Bahr|first1=Lindsey|title=Steven Spielberg's Cold War thriller and 'The BFG' snag release dates|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/06/16/steven-spielberg-cold-war-bfg/|accessdate=June 16, 2014|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=June 16, 2014}} The film was shot from September to December 2014 on location in New York City, Berlin and [[Wroclaw]], Poland (which doubled for East Berlin), and was released on October 16, 2015.{{cite news|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Tom Hanks-Steven Spielberg Cold War Thriller Set for Oct. 16, 2015|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/tom-hanks-steven-spielberg-cold-war-thriller-set-for-oct-16-2015-1201221269/|accessdate=June 6, 2014|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 16, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Amy Ryan, Alan Alda Join Tom Hanks in Steven Spielberg's Cold War Thriller|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/amy-ryan-alan-alda-join-tom-hanks-in-steven-spielbergs-cold-war-thriller-1201266172/|accessdate=July 21, 2014|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 21, 2014}} ''Bridge of Spies'' received positive reviews from critics, and was nominated for six Academy Awards, including Best Picture; Rylance won the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]], becoming the second actor to win for a performance directed by Spielberg. Spielberg's ''[[The BFG (2016 film)|The BFG]]'' is an adaptation of [[Roald Dahl]]'s celebrated [[The BFG|children's story]], starring newcomer [[Ruby Barnhill]], and Rylance as the titular Big Friendly Giant. DreamWorks bought the rights in 2010, originally intending [[John Madden (director)|John Madden]] to direct.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/apr/28/steven-spielberg-bfg-movie-roald-dahl|title=Steven Spielberg to tackle The BFG movie|author=Andrew Pulver|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2014-04-28}} The film was the last to be written by ''E.T.'' screenwriter [[Melissa Mathison]] before she died. It was co-produced and released by [[Walt Disney Pictures]], marking the first Disney-branded film to be directed by Spielberg. ''The BFG'' premiered out of competition at the [[Cannes Film Festival]]{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/cannes-film-festival-2016-official-selection-lineup-full-list-1201736807/|title=Cannes Film Festival 2016 Lineup: 'The BFG', 'Nice Guys', Penn, Refn, Almodóvar & More Confirmed; No Closing-Night Pic|first=Nancy Tartaglione,Ali|last=Jaafar|date=April 14, 2016|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=December 1, 2017}} on May 14, 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/press/programmation/?date=2016-05-14#|title=Programme|website=[[Cannes Film Festival|Festival de Cannes]]|accessdate=December 1, 2017}} and received a wide release in the US on July 1, 2016. Spielberg directed Tom Hanks and [[Meryl Streep]] in ''[[The Post (film)|The Post]]'', an account of ''[[The Washington Post]]'''s printing of the [[Pentagon Papers]].{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/steven-spielberg-tom-hanks-meryl-streep-pentagon-papers-oscar-race-the-post-1202040913/|title=Spielberg, Hanks & Streep's Pentagon Papers Pic A Contender In Next Oscar Race|last=Fleming, Jr.|first=Mike|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=March 10, 2017|accessdate=March 30, 2017}} Production began in New York on May 30, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/Production-Underway-on-Spielbergs-THE-PAPERS-Starring-Meryl-Streep-Tom-Hanks-20170606|title=Production Underway on Spielberg's THE PAPERS, Starring Meryl Streep & Tom Hanks|website=Broadwayworld.com|accessdate=December 1, 2017}} The film began a limited release on December 22, 2017, with a wide release following on January 12, 2018.{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/04/22/queen-bohemian-rhapsody-steven-spielberg-pentagon-papers-release-dates/|title=Steven Spielberg, Bryan Singer's Queen Film Land Awards Season Releases|website=Ew.com|accessdate=December 1, 2017}} Spielberg directed the [[Ready Player One (film)|film adaptation]] of the popular sci-fi novel ''[[Ready Player One]]'', by [[Ernest Cline]]. The film stars [[Tye Sheridan]],{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/tye-sheridan-lands-lead-in-steven-spielbergs-ready-player-one-20160225|title=Tye Sheridan Lands Lead In Steven Spielberg's 'Ready Play – The Playlist|author=Kevin Jagernauth|date=February 25, 2016|work=The Playlist|accessdate=March 10, 2016}} [[Olivia Cooke]],{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/me-earl-the-dying-girl-bates-motel-star-olivia-cooke-wins-lead-in-steven-spielbergs-ready-player-one-20150911|title='Me, Earl & The Dying Girl' & 'Bates Motel' Star Olivia C – The Playlist|author=Oliver Lyttelton|date=September 11, 2015|work=The Playlist}} [[Ben Mendelsohn]], [[Simon Pegg]] and [[Mark Rylance]].{{Cite news|last=McNary|first=Dave|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/steven-spielberg-ready-player-one-mark-rylance-1201752474/|title=Mark Rylance Joins Steven Spielberg's 'Ready Player One'|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|date=April 13, 2016|accessdate=July 4, 2016}} It began production in London in July 2016,{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2016/06/26/bfg-steven-spielberg-mark-rylance/86164382/|title=New BFFs Spielberg, Rylance team up for 'The BFG' and big things beyond|access-date=July 4, 2016}} a year before ''The Post'', which was filmed, edited and released during the lengthy, effects-heavy post-production period for ''Ready Player One''. ''Ready Player One'' was originally slated to be released on December 15, 2017{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2015/08/steven-spielbergs-ready-player-one-december-15-2017-release-warner-bros-1201493651/|title=Steven Spielberg’s ‘Ready Player One’ Slotted For December 2017|author=Mike Fleming Jr|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation|Penske Business Media, LLC]]|date=August 6, 2015|accessdate=March 10, 2018}} by [[Warner Bros.]],{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/ready-player-one-movie-steven-spielberg-ernest-cline-warner-bros-1201398299/|title=Steven Spielberg To Direct Sci-Fi Cult Favorite 'Ready Player One'; Back At Warner Bros.|author=Anita Busch|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=2015-03-25}} but was pushed back to March 29, 2018, to avoid competition with ''[[Star Wars: The Last Jedi]]''.{{cite news|last=Lang|first=Brent|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/ready-player-one-steven-spielberg-star-wars-1201701175/|title=Steven Spielberg's 'Ready Player One' Pushed Back to Avoid 'Star Wars: Episode VIII'|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|date=February 9, 2016|accessdate=February 9, 2016}} It had its world premiere at the [[South by Southwest]] film festival, on March 11, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/spielbergs-ready-player-one-premiere-hit-with-technical-difficulties-1202723753/|title=Spielberg's 'Ready Player One' Premiere Hit With Technical Difficulties|first=Variety|last=Staff|date=March 12, 2018|publisher=}} ===Upcoming projects=== During an interview with ''[[The Tech (newspaper)|The Tech]]'' in 2015, Spielberg described how he chooses the film projects he would work on:
[Sometimes], a story speaks to me, even if it doesn't speak to any of my collaborators or any of my partners, who look at me and scratch their heads and say, 'Gee, are you sure you wanna get into that trench for a year and a half?' I love people challenging me that way because it's a real test about my own convictions and [whether] I can be the standing man of my own life and take a stand on a subject that may not be popular, but that I would be proud to add to the body of my work. That's pretty much the litmus test that gets me to say, 'Yeah, I'll direct that one.'{{cite web|last1=Wang|first1=Ray|title=The Tech talks to Steven Spielberg|url=https://thetech.com/2015/10/22/spielberginterview-v135-n28|website=[[The Tech (newspaper)|The Tech]]|publisher=The Tech|accessdate=March 10, 2018|date=October 22, 2015}}
Spielberg plans to direct a new film adaptation of the musical ''[[West Side Story]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/03/fox-revives-west-side-story-for-steven-spielberg-as-town-ponders-stacey-snider-move-and-dreamworks-future/|title='West Side Story' Remake For Steven Spielberg In Works At Fox – Deadline|author=Mike Fleming Jr|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation|Penske Business Media, LLC]]|date=2014-03-05}} [[Tony Kushner]] stated in July 2017 that he is adapting the classic show's book for Spielberg, though the musical score will remain unchanged, as will the late-1950s setting.{{cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/tony-kushner-why-im-writing-a-play-about-donald-trump|title=Tony Kushner: Why I'm Writing a Play About Donald Trump|first=Tim|last=Teeman|date=July 19, 2017|accessdate=December 1, 2017|newspaper=The Daily Beast}} In January 2018, he began an open casting search for the four lead roles, three of the roles being specifically for Latino actors.{{cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/west-side-story-steven-spielberg-looks-spanish-speaking-actors-his-remake-1078559|title=Steven Spielberg Looks for Spanish-Speaking Actors for His 'West Side Story' Remake|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries|Eldridge Industries, LLC]]|accessdate=January 28, 2018}} On October 2, 2018, it was announced that [[Ansel Elgort]] will play the lead role of Tony in the film.{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Ansel Elgort to Star in Steven Spielberg's 'West Side Story'|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/ansel-elgort-nabs-male-lead-steven-spielbergs-west-side-story-1148420|accessdate=October 2, 2018|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries|Eldridge Industries LLC]]|date=October 2, 2018}} Spielberg also plans to film a fifth installment in the [[Indiana Jones (franchise)|''Indiana Jones'' series]]. The untitled film is set to star [[Harrison Ford]] and will be produced by [[Kathleen Kennedy (producer)|Kathleen Kennedy]] and [[Frank Marshall (producer)|Frank Marshall]]. It is being written by [[David Koepp]], who has written numerous other films for Spielberg, including the last ''Indiana Jones'' film.{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/indiana-jones-5-writer-david-koepp-1201733969/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|title='Indiana Jones 5' Taps Writer David Koepp, a Steven Spielberg Regular|last=Kroll|first=Justin|date=March 18, 2016|accessdate=July 4, 2016}} It was originally set for release by Disney on July 19, 2019.{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/steven-spielberg-harrison-ford-team-up-for-indiana-jones-5-disney-sets-july-2019-release-1201720725/|title=Steven Spielberg & Harrison Ford Team Up For ‘Indiana Jones 5’; Disney Sets July 2019 Release|last=D'Alessandro|first=Anthony|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation|Penske Business Media, LLC]]|date=March 15, 2016|accessdate=July 4, 2016}} It was then announced that filming would begin in the UK in April 2019{{cite web|url=https://theplaylist.net/spielberg-indy-5-20180319/|title=Spielberg Confirms 'Indy 5' Will Begin Production In April 2019|date=March 19, 2018|publisher=}} and the film was given a new release date of July 10, 2020.{{cite web|url=http://www.starwars.com/news/star-wars-episode-ix-and-next-indiana-jones-get-release-dates|title=Star Wars: Episode IX and Next Indiana Jones Get Release Dates|website=Starwars.com|accessdate=December 1, 2017}} Filming was postponed again in June 2018, when [[Jonathan Kasdan]] was announced as the film's new writer.{{Cite web | url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/indiana-jones-5-release-date-spielberg-harrison-ford-1202861005/ | title='Indiana Jones 5' Will Miss 2020 Release Date (EXCLUSIVE)| date=2018-06-28}} Soon after, a new release date of July 9, 2021 was announced.{{Cite web | url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/indiana-jones-5-release-date-pushed-again-2021-1125975 | title=Disney Pushes 'Indiana Jones 5' a Year to 2021, Dates 'Maleficent 2,' 'Jungle Cruise'}} Spielberg had planned to film his long-planned adaptation of [[David Kertzer]]'s ''The Kidnapping of [[Edgardo Mortara]]'' in early 2017 for release at the end of that year,{{Cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/steven-spielberg-the-kidnapping-of-edgardo-mortara-next-movie-mark-rylance-tony-kushner-1201735799/|title=Steven Spielberg Sets 'The Kidnapping Of Edgardo Mortara' Next; Tony Kushner Script, Mark Rylance Is Pope Pius IX|last=Jr|first=Mike Fleming|date=April 11, 2016|accessdate=July 4, 2016}} but production has been postponed. The book follows the true story of a young Jewish boy in 1858 Italy who was secretly baptized by a family servant and then kidnapped from his family by the Papal States, where he was raised and trained as a priest, causing international outrage and becoming a media sensation. It was first announced in 2014, with Kushner adapting the book for the screen.{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/steven-spielberg-tony-kushner-edgardo-mortara-1201157963/|title=Steven Spielberg Boards Religious Drama 'Edgardo Mortara' (Exclusive)|last=Kroll|first=Justin|date=April 18, 2014|accessdate=July 4, 2016}} [[Mark Rylance]], in his fourth consecutive collaboration with Spielberg, was announced to star in the role of [[Pope Pius IX]]. [[Oscar Isaac]] was set to star as Mortara's father, but eventually dropped out.{{cite web|url=http://screenrant.com/oscar-isaac-nazi-hunt-operation-finale/|title=Oscar Isaac Starring in Nazi Hunt Thriller Operation Finale|date=March 29, 2017|website=Screenrant.com|accessdate=December 1, 2017}} Spielberg had difficulty casting the title role, though he saw more than 2000 kids.{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/steven-spielberg-indiana-jones-west-side-story-directing-vehicles-1202262857/|date=January 19, 2018|accessdate=January 25, 2018|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation|Penske Business Media, LLC]]|title=Steven Spielberg Eyes Indiana Jones & 'West Side Story' Atop Next Directing Vehicles|first=Mike|last=Fleming Jr.}} Spielberg is attached to direct an adaptation of American photojournalist [[Lynsey Addario]]'s memoir ''It's What I Do''. [[Jennifer Lawrence]] is attached to star in the lead role.{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/steven-spielberg-jennifer-lawrence-lynsey-addario-movie/|title=Steven Spielberg to Direct Jennifer Lawrence in War Memoir Adaptation IT'S WHAT I DO|date=2015-03-02}} In April 2018, it was announced that Spielberg would be directing a film adaptation of the ''[[Blackhawk (DC Comics)|Blackhawk]]'' comic book series. [[Warner Bros. Pictures]] is distributing the film, with [[David Koepp]] writing the script.{{Cite web | url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/movies/news/steven-spielberg-to-direct-film-adaptation-of-dc's-'blackhawk'/ar-AAvZA7O?ocid=spartanntp | title=Steven Spielberg to Direct Film Adaptation of DC's 'Blackhawk'}} During an earlier interview in 1981 for ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'', Spielberg has likened the film to the ''Blackhawk'' series.{{cite web|last1=Sragow|first1=Michael|authorlink1=Michael Sragow|title=Inside 'Raiders of the Lost Ark'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/features/raiders-of-the-lost-ark-19810625|website=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=April 22, 2018|date=June 25, 1981|quote="The one [Spielberg] feels ''Raiders'' is closest to is ''Blackhawk'' – the DC comic (and 1952 Sam Katzman serial)..."}} ====Projects on hold==== In 2009, Spielberg reportedly tried to obtain the screen rights to make a film based on [[Microsoft]]'s [[Halo (series)|''Halo'' series]].{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/10/the_new_halo_video_game_is_a_h.html|title=The New Halo Game Is a Hit – So What's the Status of the Halo Movie?}} In September 2008, Steven Spielberg bought film rights for [[John Wyndham]]'s novel ''[[Chocky]]'' and is interested in directing it. He is also interested in making an adaptation of ''[[A Steady Rain]]'',{{cite web|title=SDCC: Spielberg Interested in A Steady Rain Movie|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=80084|accessdate=July 21, 2011|publisher=ComingSoon|date=2011-07-21}} ''[[Pirate Latitudes]]'',Spielberg to make pirates movie – Yahoo! Movies UK & Ireland {{cite web|url=http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/27082009/5/spielberg-pirates-movie-0.html|title=Yahoo Movies UK|accessdate=August 28, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090917051419/http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/27082009/5/spielberg-pirates-movie-0.html|archivedate=September 17, 2009 }} ''[[The 39 Clues]]'',{{cite news| author = Michael Fleming| title = Steven Spielberg follows '39 Clues'|work = Variety| date = June 24, 2008| url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117988019.html?categoryid=13&cs=1| accessdate=September 3, 2008}} and a remake of ''[[When Worlds Collide (1951 film)|When Worlds Collide]]''. In May 2009, Steven Spielberg bought the rights to the life story of [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] Spielberg will be involved not only as producer but also as a director.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/5351278/Steven-Spielberg-to-direct-Martin-Luther-King-film.html "Steven Spielberg to direct Martin Luther King film"] ''Daily Telegraph'', May 19, 2009. Footnote format December 24, 2009. However, the purchase was made from the King estate, led by son [[Dexter King|Dexter]], while the two other surviving children, the [[Bernice Albertine King|Reverend Bernice]] and [[Martin Luther King III|Martin III]], immediately threatened to sue, not having given their approvals to the project.[http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/20/kings-children-may -sue-over-planned-biographical-film/ "King's Children May Sue Over Planned Biographical Film"] by Dave Itzkoff, ''[[The New York Times]]'' ArtsBeat blog, May 20, 2009. Retrieved December 24, 2009. ===Production credits=== Since the mid-1980s, Spielberg has increased his role as a film producer. He headed up the production team for several cartoons, including the Warner Bros. hits ''[[Tiny Toon Adventures]]'', ''[[Animaniacs]]'', ''[[Pinky and the Brain]]'', ''[[Toonsylvania]]'', and ''[[Freakazoid!]]'', for which he collaborated with [[Jean MacCurdy]] and [[Tom Ruegger]]. Due to his work on these series, in the official titles, most of them say, "Steven Spielberg presents" as well as making numerous cameos on the shows. Spielberg also produced the [[Don Bluth]] animated features, ''[[An American Tail]]'' and ''[[The Land Before Time]]'', which were released by [[Universal Studios]]. He also served as one of the executive producers of ''[[Who Framed Roger Rabbit]]'' and its three related shorts (''Tummy Trouble'', ''Roller Coaster Rabbit'', ''Trail Mix-Up''), which were all released by Disney, under both the [[Walt Disney Pictures]] and the [[Touchstone Pictures]] banners. He was furthermore, for a short time, the executive producer of the long-running medical drama ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]''. In 1989, he brought the concept of ''[[The Dig]]'' to [[LucasArts]]. He contributed to the project from that time until 1995 when the game was released. He also collaborated with software publishers [[Knowledge Adventure]] on the multimedia game ''[[Steven Spielberg's Director's Chair]]'', which was released in 1996. Spielberg appears, as himself, in the game to direct the player. The Spielberg name provided branding for a [[Lego]] Moviemaker kit, the proceeds of which went to the Starbright Foundation. [[File:Steven Spielberg 1999.jpg|thumb|left|Spielberg speaking at the Pentagon on August 11, 1999 after receiving the Department of Defense Medal for Distinguished Public Service from Secretary of Defense [[William S. Cohen]]]] In 1993, Spielberg acted as executive producer for the highly anticipated television series ''[[seaQuest DSV]]''; a science fiction series set "in the near future" starring [[Roy Scheider]] (who Spielberg had directed in ''Jaws'') and [[Jonathan Brandis]] that aired on [[NBC]]. While the first season was moderately successful, the second season did less well. Spielberg's name no longer appeared in the third season and the show was cancelled midway through it. Spielberg served as an uncredited executive producer on ''[[The Haunting (1999 film)|The Haunting]]'', ''[[The Prince of Egypt]]'', ''[[Just Like Heaven (film)|Just Like Heaven]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/386887.If_Only_It_Were_True|title=If Only It Were True by Marc Levy – Reviews, Discussion, Bookclubs, Lists|publisher=Goodreads.com|accessdate=May 25, 2012}} ''[[Shrek]]'', ''[[Road to Perdition]]'',{{cite news| author=Jeff Jensen| url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,320333,00.html| title=Killer Instinct|work=Entertainment Weekly| date=July 19, 2002| accessdate=June 6, 2007 }} and ''[[Evolution (2001 film)|Evolution]]''. He served as an executive producer for the 1997 film ''[[Men in Black (1997 film)|Men in Black]]'', and its sequels, ''[[Men in Black II]]'' and ''[[Men in Black III]]''. In 2005, he served as a producer of ''[[Memoirs of a Geisha (film)|Memoirs of a Geisha]]'', an adaptation of the novel by [[Arthur Golden]], a film to which he was previously attached as director. In 2006, Spielberg co-executive produced with famed filmmaker [[Robert Zemeckis]] a CGI children's film called ''[[Monster House (film)|Monster House]]'', marking their eighth collaboration since 1990's ''[[Back to the Future Part III]]''. He also teamed with [[Clint Eastwood]] for the first time in their careers, co-producing Eastwood's ''[[Flags of Our Fathers (film)|Flags of Our Fathers]]'' and ''[[Letters from Iwo Jima]]'' with [[Robert Lorenz]] and Eastwood himself. He earned his twelfth Academy Award nomination for the latter film as it was nominated for Best Picture. Spielberg served as executive producer for ''[[Disturbia (film)|Disturbia]]'' and the ''[[Transformers (film)|Transformers]]'' live action film with [[Brian Goldner]], an employee of [[Hasbro]]. The film was directed by [[Michael Bay]] and written by [[Roberto Orci]] and [[Alex Kurtzman]], and Spielberg continued to collaborate on the sequels, ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]'', ''[[Transformers: Dark of the Moon]]'', ''[[Transformers: Age of Extinction]]'', and ''[[Transformers: The Last Knight]]''. In 2011, he produced the [[J. J. Abrams]] science fiction thriller film ''[[Super 8 (2011 film)|Super 8]]'' for [[Paramount Pictures]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/20108|title=NEW 'Super 8' Teaser Details, Spielberg/Abrams Collaboration Confirmed!|publisher=Bloody-disgusting.com|accessdate=January 31, 2011|date=2010-05-06}} Other major television series Spielberg produced were ''[[Band of Brothers (TV miniseries)|Band of Brothers]]'', ''[[Taken (TV miniseries)|Taken]]'' and ''[[The Pacific (miniseries)|The Pacific]]''. He was an executive producer on the critically acclaimed 2005 TV miniseries ''[[Into the West (TV miniseries)|Into the West]]'' which won two Emmy awards, including one for [[Geoff Zanelli]]'s score. For his 2010 miniseries ''[[The Pacific (miniseries)|The Pacific]]'' he teamed up once again with co-producer Tom Hanks, with [[Gary Goetzman]] also co-producing'. The miniseries is believed to have cost $250 million and is a 10-part war miniseries centered on the battles in the Pacific Theater during World War II. Writer [[Bruce McKenna]], who penned several installments of (''[[Band of Brothers (TV miniseries)|Band of Brothers]]''), was the head writer. In 2007, Steven Spielberg and [[Mark Burnett (executive producer)|Mark Burnett]] co-produced ''[[On the Lot]]'' a short-lived TV reality show about filmmaking. Despite this, he never gave up working on television. He currently serves as one of the executive producers on ''[[United States of Tara]]'', a show created by [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Academy Award]] [[Juno (film)|winner]] [[Diablo Cody]] which they developed together (Spielberg is uncredited as creator). In 2011, Spielberg launched ''[[Falling Skies]]'', a science fiction television series, on the [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]] network. He developed the series with [[Robert Rodat]] and is credited as an executive producer. Spielberg is also producing the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] TV series ''[[Terra Nova (TV series)|Terra Nova]]''. ''Terra Nova'' begins in the year 2149 when all life on the planet Earth is threatened with extinction resulting in scientists opening a door that allows people to travel back 85 million years to Spielberg also served as an executive producer on the series.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/02/five-came-back-netflix-trailer-spielberg-coppola-del-toro-greengrass-kasdan-1202026705/|title='Netflix's 'Five Came Back' With Spielberg, Coppola, Del Toro, Greengrass & Kasdan Drops Trailer – Watch|first=Anita|last=Busch|date=February 28, 2017|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=December 1, 2017}} === Involvement in video games === Apart from being an ardent gamer Spielberg has had a long history of involvement in video games.{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7260228.stm|title=Making games with Steven Spielberg|publisher=BBC News|date=February 23, 2008|accessdate=January 6, 2010|first=Darren|last=Waters}} He has been giving thanks to his games of his division [[DreamWorks Interactive]] as ''Someone's in the Kitchen'' with script written by [[Animaniacs]]' [[Paul Rugg]], ''[[Escape from HorrorLand|Goosebumps: Escape from HorrorLand]]'', ''[[The Neverhood]]'' (all in 1996), ''[[Skullmonkeys]]'', ''[[Dilbert's Desktop Games]]'', ''[[Goosebumps: Attack of the Mutant]]'' (all 1997), ''[[Boombots]]'' (1999), ''[[T'ai Fu: Wrath of the Tiger]]'' (1999), and ''[[Clive Barker's Undying]]'' (2001).
